questions.text: The boundaries of the perineum include all the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sacrospinous ligament is not part of the perineal boundary but instead contributes to the formation of pelvic foramina.

  • The perineum is a diamond-shaped region below the pelvic diaphragm.
  • It is bounded:
    • Anteriorly by the pubic symphysis
    • Anterolaterally by the ischiopubic rami(Option A ruled out)
    • Laterally by the ischial tuberosities(Option B ruled out)
    • Posterolaterally by the sacrotuberous ligaments
    • Posteriorly by the tip of the coccyx(Option D ruled out)

Division of the perineum:

  • The perineum is divided into two triangles by an imaginary line joining the ischial tuberosities:
    1. Urogenital Triangle (anterior)
      • Boundaries: Pubic symphysis, ischiopubic rami, and line between ischial tuberosities
      • Contains: External genitalia, urethral opening
    2. Anal Triangle (posterior)
      • Boundaries: Tip of the coccyx and sacrotuberous ligaments
      • Contains: Anal canal, ischioanal fossae
  • The sacrospinous ligament connects the sacrum to the ischial spine and lies deeper in the pelvis, helping form the greater and lesser sciatic foramina-not a surface boundary of the perineum.

Key Takeaway:

The sacrospinous ligament forms part of the pelvic wall anatomy but does not contribute to the surface boundaries of the perineum.

questions.text: A condensation of fibrous tissue in the female located at the centre of the posterior border of the perineal membrane is the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The perineal body is a fibromuscular node situated at the center of the posterior border of the perineal membrane and serves as the convergence point of multiple perineal muscles.

  • It acts as a key structural support to the perineum, especially in females.
  • Attachments to the perineal body include:
    • Bilateral superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
    • Bulbospongiosus muscle
    • External anal sphincter
    • Levator ani (some fibres)
  • Located at the junction of the urogenital and anal triangles, it plays a critical role during childbirth.
  • The male equivalent is known as the central tendinous point of the perineum.

Explanation of other options:

Posterior labial commissure (Option A): External genital landmark, superficial and not related to fibromuscular support.

Anococcygeal ligament (Option C): Fibrous band between the anus and coccyx; located in the anal triangle, not at the perineal membrane.

Pubovesical ligament (Option D): Connects the bladder to the pubic bone-supports pelvic viscera, not part of the perineal membrane.

Key Takeaway:

The perineal body is the central fibromuscular anchor at the posterior margin of the perineal membrane, where several muscles insert.

questions.text: The artery that supplies blood to the major erectile body in both the males and females is the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The deep artery of the penis or clitoris supplies the corpus cavernosum-the primary erectile body in both sexes-and arises from the internal pudendal artery.

In the above diagram:

  • A: Inferior rectal artery
  • B: Deep artery of penis or clitoris
  • C: Dorsal artery of penis or clitoris
  • D: Artery of the bulb

Key Takeaway:

The deep artery of the penis or clitoris, arising from the internal pudendal artery, is the principal vessel supplying the corpus cavernosum, the primary erectile body in both sexes.

questions.text: The vestibular bulbs/bulb of the corpus spongiosum are firmly attached to the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The bulb of the corpus spongiosum or vestibular bulbs are anchored to the perineal membrane and are covered by the bulbospongiosus muscle.

  • These erectile tissues are part of the superficial perineal pouch, resting directly on the inferior surface of the perineal membrane.
  • They function in sexual arousal, contributing to erection in males (bulb of penis) and swelling of vestibule in females (bulbs of vestibule).
  • Covered by the bulbospongiosus muscle, which compresses them during contraction to aid in erection and ejaculation.
  • The crura of the corpora cavernosa (not bulbs) attach to the ischiopubic rami and the perineal membrane.

Explanation of other options:

Superior pubic rami (Option B): Part of the pelvic bone; gives origin to crura.

Ischiopubic rami (Option C): Provide attachment for crura of corpora cavernosa.

Pubic symphysis (Option D): Midline bony joint-related to suspensory ligament of penis/clitoris but not bulb attachment.

Key Takeaway:

The vestibular bulbs or bulb of corpus spongiosum lie within the superficial perineal pouch and are firmly attached to the perineal membrane.

questions.text: The part of the male reproductive tract that carries only semen within the prostate gland is the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ejaculatory duct runs through the prostate gland and carries only semen (sperm + seminal fluid), unlike the prostatic urethra, which also carries urine.

The ejaculatory duct is a narrow duct formed by the:

  • Ampulla of the ductus deferens and
  • Duct of the seminal vesicle

It traverses the prostate gland and empties into the prostatic urethra.

It carries only semen, which is a mixture of:

  • Sperm from the ductus deferens
  • Seminal fluid from the seminal vesicle
  • Prostatic secretions (added later)

It does not carry urine, unlike the prostatic urethra and the membranous urethra.

Therefore, it is the only segment within the prostate exclusively dedicated to semen.

Key Takeaway:

The ejaculatory duct is the only duct within the prostate that transports semen exclusively, without urine involvement.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of blunt trauma to the pelvis and was diagnosed with urethral rupture. Imaging revealed extravasation of the urine into the superficial perineal pouch. The attachment of which of the following fascia prevents extravasation into the thigh and anal triangle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Colles' fascia, the membranous layer of superficial perineal fascia, is firmly attached laterally to the ischiopubic rami and posteriorly to the perineal membrane, preventing urine from spreading into the thigh and anal triangle.

  • Colles' fascia is the deep membranous layer of superficial perineal fascia, continuous with Scarpa's fascia from the anterior abdominal wall.
  • It forms the external limit of the superficial perineal pouch and lines the scrotum, penis, and labia.
  • Attachments:
    • Posteriorly: to the perineal membrane, preventing posterior spread into the anal triangle.
    • Laterally, it is to the fascia lata of the thigh (at Holden's line) and ischiopubic rami, preventing it from spreading into the thigh.
    • Anteriorly, it is continuous with Scarpa's fascia, allowing it to spread up to the anterior abdominal wall.

Explanation of other options:

Scarpa's fascia (Option A): Abdominal fascia; continues into the perineum but lacks a direct role in perineal containment.

Deep perineal fascia (Option C): Covers perineal muscles; not a limiting layer for superficial extravasation.

Buck's fascia (Option D): Deep fascia of the penis; rupture below it leads to deep extravasation, not superficial.

Key Takeaway:

Colles' fascia prevents urine from entering the thigh and anal triangle after urethral rupture by attaching to the fascia lata and perineal membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tributary of the common iliac vein?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lateral sacral veins occasionally drain directly into the common iliac vein, unlike other pelvic veins that drain into the internal iliac vein.

The lateral sacral vein is a tributary of the common iliac vein.

Tributaries of the common iliac vein:

  • Median sacral veins
  • Iliolumbar vein
  • Lateral sacral veins (occasionally)

Tributaries of the internal iliac vein:

  • Superior and inferior gluteal veins(Option B, C ruled out)
  • Internal pudendal vein
  • Obturator vein
  • Lateral sacral veins

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman in labour requires regional anaesthesia but has a contraindication to epidural anaesthesia. The needle is guided toward the bony prominence highlighted in red in the image below.
Which of the following nerves is blocked at this bony landmark?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ischial spine serves as the key landmark for administering a pudendal nerve block.

  • The pudendal nerve arises from S2-S4 spinal roots and is the main nerve of the perineum.
  • It exits the pelvic cavity via the greater sciatic foramen, curves around the ischial spine and sacrospinous ligament, and re-enters the perineum through the lesser sciatic foramen.
  • The ischial spine, highlighted in the image, is palpable transvaginally and serves as the needle target during pudendal nerve block.
  • A transvaginal pudendal block is used to anesthetize the perineum, including the external anal sphincter, external urethral sphincter, and surrounding skin.
  • This block is an alternative for women who cannot receive epidural anaesthesia, or for chronic pelvic pain and minor perineal procedures.

Explanation of other options:

Sciatic nerve (Option B): Exits greater sciatic foramen but travels posteriorly; not in contact with ischial spine.

Obturator nerve (Option C): Travels through the obturator canal; unrelated to the ischial spine.

Femoral nerve (Option D): Lies anteriorly in the thigh; unrelated to pelvic bony landmarks.

Key Takeaway:

The pudendal nerve curves around the ischial spine, making it the anatomical target for pudendal nerve block during labour or perineal procedures.

questions.text: What part of the ischioanal (ischiorectal) fossa extends deep to the sacrotuberous ligament?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The posterior recess of the ischioanal fossa extends deep to the sacrotuberous ligament and lies superior to the gluteus maximus.

  • The ischioanal fossa is a fat-filled wedge-shaped space located lateral to the anal canal and inferior to the pelvic diaphragm.
  • It permits expansion of the anal canal during defecation.
  • It has anterior and posterior recesses that allow extension of infection or fluid.

Explanation of other options:

Anterior recess (Option A): Extends anteriorly above the perineal membrane into the urogenital triangle, not posteriorly.

Genital hiatus (Option B): Refers to the gap in the pelvic diaphragm for urethra/vagina and anus-not a recess of the ischioanal fossa.

Pudendal canal (Option D): A neurovascular passageway on the lateral wall of the fossa, not an anatomical recess.

Key Takeaways:

  • The posterior recess is the part of the ischioanal fossa that extends beneath the sacrotuberous ligament.
  • The ischioanal fossa supports key perineal structures and provides space for expansion and surgical access.
  • Infections or abscesses can spread between the anterior and posterior recesses.

choices.text: The urogenital and anal triangles are divided by a line joining the ischial spines
The anal triangle lies anterior to the urogenital triangle
A line joining the ischial tuberosities divides the perineum into anterior and posterior triangles
The perineum is located superior to the pelvic floor

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the perineum is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A line connecting the ischial tuberosities divides the perineum into an anterior urogenital triangle and a posterior anal triangle.

  • The perineum is the region inferior to the pelvic floor and between the thighs.
  • It is bounded by the pelvic outlet and is shaped like a diamond in anatomical position.
  • A transverse line connecting the ischial tuberosities divides this space into:
    • Anterior (urogenital) triangle, which contains:
      • Roots of the external genitalia
      • Openings of the urethra and vagina in females
      • Distal urethra and external genitalia in males
    • Posterior (anal) triangle, which contains:
      • Anal canal and anus

Explanation of other options:

Ischial spines (Option A): Located higher and deeper in the pelvis; not used to divide the perineum.

Anal triangle anterior (Option B): The anal triangle lies posterior, not anterior, to the urogenital triangle.

Perineum superior (Option D): The perineum is below the pelvic floor, not above it.

Key Takeaways:

  • The perineum is anatomically divided into two triangles using the inter-ischial line.
  • Each triangle houses distinct anatomical contents based on gender.
  • Understanding this layout is essential for clinical procedures involving the perineum.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with the following findings. Weakness of which of the following muscles could not have led to this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ischiococcygeus is not part of the levator ani and does not directly support pelvic viscera, so its weakness does not contribute to uterine prolapse.

  • The levator ani group includes puborectalis, pubococcyx, and iliococcyx, all of which are essential for pelvic organ support. (Option A, B, C ruled out)
  • Uterine prolapse results from weakening or damage to these pelvic diaphragm muscles.
  • The ischiococcygeus (or coccygeus) lies posterior to the levator ani and overlies the sacrospinous ligament. It contributes to the posterior pelvic floor but not directly to visceral support.

Key Takeaways:

  • The levator ani (not the coccyx) is crucial in maintaining pelvic organ position.
  • Uterine prolapse typically follows damage to the levator ani during childbirth or ageing.
  • Coccyx (ischiococcyx) plays a minor role in pelvic support.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with adenocarcinoma in the wall of the rectal ampulla undergoes pelvic MRI. The scan shows tumour infiltration into the muscle lying immediately lateral to the ampulla. Which muscle is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The levator ani lies immediately lateral to the rectal ampulla and is the first muscle to be infiltrated in the local spread of rectal cancer.

  • The ampulla of the rectum is surrounded inferolaterally by the levator ani, which forms the medial part of the pelvic floor.
  • In the context of pelvic malignancies, especially rectal tumours, involvement of the levator ani signifies advanced local spread.
  • Obturator internus and piriformis are located more laterally/posteriorly and are not in direct contact with the rectal wall.
  • The sphincter urethrae lies in the deep perineal pouch and is not anatomically related to the rectal ampulla.

Explanation of other options:

Piriformis (Option A): Lies posterior to the rectum and forms part of the posterior pelvic wall, not in close contact with the rectal ampulla.

Obturator internus (Option B): Forms the lateral pelvic wall and is separated from the rectum by the levator ani.

Sphincter urethrae (Option D): Lies in the deep perineal pouch around the urethra, not adjacent to the rectum.

Key Takeaways:

  • The levator ani is the main muscle lateral to the rectal ampulla.
  • Tumour infiltration here suggests spread beyond the rectal wall.
  • Understanding pelvic muscle anatomy is critical in staging rectal cancers.

questions.text: Blood supply to the superior portions of the bladder typically arises from the ____________ arteries.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The umbilical artery gives rise to the superior vesical arteries, which supply the superior part of the urinary bladder.

  • In males, the umbilical artery also gives off an artery to the ductus deferens.
  • Beyond its patent segment, the umbilical artery becomes obliterated and forms the medial umbilical ligament.
  • The superior vesical arteries are the key source of blood to the bladder dome and upper body.

Explanation of other options:

Middle rectal (Option B): Supplies the middle portion of the rectum and seminal vesicles.

Obturator (Option C): Primarily supplies the medial thigh and hip; rarely contributes to pelvic organs.

Inferior gluteal (Option D): Supplies gluteal muscles and adjacent structures.

Key Takeaways:

  • Superior vesical arteries from the umbilical artery supply the superior bladder.
  • Additional supply to the bladder may come from inferior vesical arteries (in males) or vaginal arteries (in females).
  • The vesical venous plexus drains into the internal iliac veins and communicates with the prostatic/uterine venous plexuses.

questions.text: The pelvic splanchnic nerves primarily carry ____________ to the _____________ plexus.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pelvic splanchnic nerves are unique among splanchnics as they carry preganglionic parasympathetic fibres (from spinal cord segments S2-S4) to the inferior hypogastric plexus.

  • These nerves contribute to autonomic control of pelvic viscera such as the bladder, rectum, and reproductive organs.
  • They synapse in pelvic ganglia within the inferior hypogastric plexus, and postganglionic fibres innervate pelvic smooth muscle and glands.
  • This parasympathetic innervation controls visceral motility, secretion, and micturition.
  • In contrast, the superior hypogastric plexus is primarily sympathetic and connects with the inferior hypogastric plexus via hypogastric nerves.

Key Takeaway:

Pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4) uniquely carry preganglionic parasympathetic fibres to the inferior hypogastric plexus, supporting visceral functions of the pelvic organs.

questions.text: The sacral outflow of the parasympathetic (craniosacral) system enters the pelvic plexus via:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pelvic splanchnic nerves are preganglionic parasympathetic fibres originating from spinal cord levels S2 to S4, entering the inferior hypogastric plexus to supply pelvic viscera.

  • These nerves are the only parasympathetic splanchnic nerves in the body.
  • They provide autonomic innervation to the bladder, distal colon, rectum, and erectile tissues.
  • Their contribution, along with sympathetic fibres from hypogastric and sacral splanchnic nerves, forms the inferior hypogastric plexus.
  • This plexus further branches into rectal, uterovaginal, vesical, and prostatic plexuses, supplying corresponding pelvic organs.
  • Disruption of this system (e.g. during prostatectomy) may result in loss of autonomic control, including erectile dysfunction or bladder issues.

Explanation of other options:

Hypogastric nerves (Option A): Carry sympathetic fibres from the superior hypogastric plexus-not parasympathetic.

Pudendal nerves (Option C): Somatic motor and sensory nerves of S2-S4-not involved in autonomic pelvic innervation.

Sacral splanchnic nerves (Option D): Sympathetic fibres from sacral sympathetic trunk-not parasympathetic.

Key Takeaway:

Pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4) are the sole parasympathetic outflow to pelvic viscera, entering the inferior hypogastric plexus.

choices.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia
It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament
It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon
Its fibres fan out with the fascia iliaca laterally

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The iliopubic tract is a condensation of the transversalis fascia that blends laterally with the fascia iliaca, forming part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and an important surgical landmark.

  • It lies posterior (deep) to the inguinal ligament, not anterior to it (Option B ruled out).
  • It is not a thickening of the lumbar fascia; instead, it arises from the transversalis fascia (Option A ruled out).
  • It does not insert into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon but passes posterior to the conjoint tendon, attaching medially to the pubic bone and Cooper's ligament (Option C ruled out).
  • Laterally, its fibres fan out and merge with the fascia iliaca overlying the iliacus and psoas muscles, marking the correct statement (Option D ruled out).

Key Takeaway:

The iliopubic tract is a thickened part of the transversalis fascia running deep to the inguinal ligament and blending laterally with the fascia iliaca-an important landmark in hernia surgeries.

choices.text: Contraction leads to occlusion of the vaginal canal
Puborectalis and pubococcyx create the anorectal angle
Arises from the condensation of the piriformis fascia

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the levator ani muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The levator ani arises from the obturator fascia (tendinous arch), not from the piriformis fascia.

  • Components: The levator ani consists of pubococcyx, puborectalis, and iliococcygeus.
  • Origin: Arises from the posterior pubic bone, tendinous arch of the obturator internus fascia, and the ischial spine.
  • Nerve Supply: Receives innervation from S4 (direct branch) and the inferior rectal nerve from the pudendal nerve (S2-S4).
  • Function:
    • Supports the pelvic organs by forming the pelvic diaphragm.
    • Contributes to the vaginal, rectal, and urethral occlusion by tonic contraction (Option A ruled out).
    • Puborectalis and pubococcyxgeus maintain the anorectal angle, critical for continence (Option B ruled out).
    • It reinforces the external anal sphincter, helping to maintain resting rectal tone (Option C ruled out).

Key Takeaway:

Levator ani supports pelvic organs, maintains continence via the anorectal angle, and originates from the obturator fascia, not the piriformis fascia.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does NOT arise from the anterior division of the internal iliac artery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The iliolumbar artery arises from the posterior division of the internal iliac artery, not the anterior division.

  • The internal iliac artery divides into anterior and posterior trunks at the level of the greater sciatic foramen.
  • Branches of the anterior division include:
    • Umbilical artery (gives off the superior vesical artery)
    • Obturator artery (Option D ruled out)
    • Inferior vesical/vaginal artery
    • Middle rectal artery
    • Uterine and vaginal arteries (in females)
    • Internal pudendal artery (Option A ruled out)
    • Inferior gluteal artery (Option B ruled out)
  • Branches of the posterior division include:
    • Iliolumbar artery
    • Lateral sacral artery
    • Superior gluteal artery

Key Takeaway:

The iliolumbar artery is a branch of the posterior division, not the anterior division, of the internal iliac artery.

choices.text: The external iliac vein lies medial to the external iliac artery
The external iliac veins join to form the inferior vena cava
The inferior vena cava cannot be imaged
Pelvic veins are usually imaged using an arteriogram

questions.text: Which statement is true regarding pelvic veins?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The external iliac vein lies medial to the external iliac artery as they course along the pelvic brim toward the inguinal ligament.

  • The external iliac vein begins as a continuation of the femoral vein, ascending along the pelvic brim, and lies medial to the external iliac artery.
  • It joins with the internal iliac vein to form the common iliac vein, which contributes to the formation of the inferior vena cava (IVC).
  • This anatomical positioning is clinically significant in surgeries involving the pelvic inlet and hernia repairs.

Explanation of Other Options:

External iliac veins join to form the inferior vena cava (Option B): Common iliac veins, not external iliac veins, unite to form the inferior vena cava.

Inferior vena cava cannot be imaged (Option C): IVC can be visualised using imaging modalities like CT, MRI, or venography.

Pelvic veins are usually imaged using an arteriogram (Option D): Arteriograms are for arteries; veins are imaged using venography or Doppler ultrasound.

Key Takeaway:

The external iliac vein lies medial to its accompanying artery and plays a key role in pelvic venous drainage.

choices.text: Along with the pelvic brim, it defines the true pelvic cavity
It is a funnel-shaped skeletal muscle
It is referred to as the pelvic diaphragm

questions.text: Which statement about the pelvic floor is NOT correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pelvic floor is not tensed during defecation-it is relaxed to permit the passage of faeces. During defecation:

  • The levator ani muscle and external anal sphincter must relax to open the anorectal angle.
  • Contraction of these muscles maintains continence; relaxation allows expulsion.
  • Parasympathetic innervation (via pelvic splanchnic nerves) leads to contraction of the rectum and relaxation of the internal anal sphincter.
  • Voluntary control over external sphincters allows defecation to be deferred.

Key Concepts about the Pelvic Floor:

  • Formed by the levator ani and coccyxmuscles.
  • Shaped like a funnel or bowl, separates the pelvic cavity from the perineum.
  • Urethra, vagina (in females), and anal canal pass through openings in this floor.
  • Provides support for pelvic viscera and maintains continence.
  • The levator ani arises from the pubic bone and tendinous arch of the obturator fascia, inserting posteriorly into the anococcygeal ligament and coccyx.

Explanation of other options:

Along with the pelvic brim, it defines the true pelvic cavity (Option A): True. The pelvic floor marks the inferior boundary; the pelvic brim defines the inlet.

It is attached to the pelvic wall and forms a muscular funnel with midline raphe (Option B): True. The levator ani muscles attach to the pelvic walls and join in the midline to form the pelvic diaphragm.

It is referred to as the pelvic diaphragm(Option C): True. The pelvic floor is also known as the pelvic diaphragm, composed of skeletal muscle and fascia.

Key Takeaway:

The pelvic floor is relaxed-not tensed-during defecation to allow the passage of stool.

questions.text: Following pregnancy and delivery, a 32-year-old woman continued to have problems with urinary incontinence, which developed during pregnancy. Her obstetrician counseled her to strengthen the muscle bordering the vagina and urethra, increasing its tone and exerting pressure on the urethra. This physical therapy was soon adequate to restore urinary continence. What muscle was strengthened?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Puborectalis, a component of the levator ani, forms a sling around the anorectal junction and lies closest to the urethra and vagina. It supports the pelvic viscera, contributes to the continence mechanism, and is commonly rehabilitated through Kegel exercises postpartum.

The levator ani is subdivided into:

  • Pubococcygeus, which includes fibers like pubovaginalis involved in vaginal support.
  • Puborectalis, which forms a sling at the anorectal junction and contributes to urinary and faecal continence.
  • Iliococcygeus forms the lateral part of the pelvic diaphragm.

The puborectalis and pubovaginalis portions are key to restoring tone in postpartum stress incontinence.

Explanation of other options:

Coccygeus (Option A): Supports the posterior pelvic floor; not closely associated with urethral or vaginal support.

Ischiocavernosus (Option B): Acts on erectile tissues, not involved in continence or vaginal tone.

Obturator Internus (Option C): Laterally rotates the hip; although pelvic in origin, it has no role in pelvic floor support.

Key Takeaway:

The puborectalis muscle is essential for supporting the vagina and urethra, and strengthening it through pelvic floor exercises helps improve postpartum urinary continence.

questions.text: Preganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibres within the pelvic (inferior hypogastric) plexus arise from S2, 3, 4 and enter the plexus via:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pelvic splanchnic nerves are the only splanchnic nerves that carry preganglionic parasympathetic fibres from S2-S4 to the pelvic plexus.

  • These nerves arise from the anterior rami of spinal nerves S2 to S4 and join the inferior hypogastric plexus on the lateral pelvic wall.
  • They supply parasympathetic innervation to pelvic viscera, including the rectum, bladder, and reproductive organs.
  • This pathway also mediates genital erection in both males and females.
  • The term "pelvic splanchnic" is unique because all other splanchnic nerves (thoracic, lumbar, sacral) carry sympatheticfibres.

Explanation of other options:

Grey rami communicantes (Option A): Contain postganglionic sympathetic fibres to spinal nerves; not involved in pelvic parasympathetic supply.

Hypogastric nerves (Option B): Carry sympathetic fibres from the superior hypogastric plexus to the pelvis, not parasympathetic.

Sacral splanchnic nerves (Option D): Arise from the sympathetic chain and carry sympathetic fibres, unlike pelvic splanchnics.

Key Takeaway:

Only pelvic splanchnic nerves from S2-S4 provide parasympathetic innervation to the pelvic plexus and viscera.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the anterolateral wall of the true pelvis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The obturator internus with its fascia forms the anterolateral wall of the true pelvis.

Muscles forming the walls of the true pelvis:

  • Anterolateral wall - obturator internus and the fascia over its upper and inner (pelvic) surface.
  • Posterolateral wall - piriformis
  • Floor - levator ani and coccygeus

questions.text: Which of the following does not form the bony pelvis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

L5 vertebra does not form part of the bony pelvis; it articulates with the sacrum above the pelvic inlet.

  • The bony pelvis is made up of the two hip bones, sacrum, and coccyx.
  • Each hip bone comprises three fused bones: ilium, ischium, and pubis.
  • These bones articulate to form three important pelvic joints:
    • Sacroiliac joints (between the ilium and the sacrum)
    • Pubic symphysis (between the pubic bones)
    • Sacrococcyx joint (between sacrum and coccyx)
  • Although L5 contributes structurally to the lumbosacral joint, it is not part of the bony pelvis, as it lies above the pelvic inlet and belongs to the lumbar spine.

Key Takeaway:

L5 vertebra is not part of the bony pelvis-it lies above the pelvic inlet and belongs to the lumbar vertebrae.

questions.text: While performing a hysterectomy, the resident must ligate the uterine artery. To avoid iatrogenic injury to the ureters, she must be aware that the ureter passes ___________ the artery at the level of the ______________.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ureter passes under the uterine artery near the cervix, a relationship remembered by the surgical phrase "water under the bridge."

  • At the level of the lateral fornix of the vagina, the uterine artery crosses over the ureter.
  • This relationship occurs in the inferior portion of the mesometrium, near the cervix, making the site prone to ureteric injury during hysterectomy.
  • The pelvic splanchnic nerves and vascular structures also travel nearby, so precise dissection is essential.
  • Iatrogenic ureteral injury can result in urine leakage, uretero-vaginal fistula, or renal compromise, especially when unrecognised intraoperatively.

Key Takeaway:

During hysterectomy, surgeons must remember that the ureter passes under the uterine artery near the cervix to prevent injury.

questions.text: A patient presents complaining of blood-stained stools and the inability to empty his rectum. He also has pain along the back of his thigh and weakness of the posterior thigh muscles. Digital examination reveals a tumour in the posterolateral wall of the rectum. Pressure on which nerve plexus could cause the pain in his lower limb?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sacral plexus lies on the anterior surface of the piriformis, which is part of the posterolateral pelvic wall, near the rectum. A tumour in this region can compress the sacral plexus, leading to both pelvic floor dysfunction and pain/weakness in the posterior thigh.

  • The sacral plexus is formed by the lumbosacral trunk (L4-L5) and anterior rami of S1-S4.
  • It gives rise to motor branches to the levator ani and coccyx, and major nerves, including the sciatic and pudendal.
  • Tumours in the posterolateral rectal wall may compress the plexus, causing motor weakness of the posterior thigh, pain along the sciatic nerve, and pelvic floor dysfunction (e.g. difficulty in rectal evacuation).

Explanation of other options:

Inferior hypogastric (Option A): Supplies autonomic fibres to pelvic organs but not somatic motor to the posterior thigh.

Inferior mesenteric (Option B): Part of the autonomic supply to the hindgut; not involved in somatic thigh innervation.

Lumbar (Option C): Supplies anterior thigh via femoral and obturator nerves-not the posterior thigh.

Key Takeaway:

Compression of the sacral plexus, located on the anterior surface of the piriformis, can lead to both pelvic organ symptoms and posterior thigh pain/weakness.

questions.text: A patient with sciatica was found to have inflammation of the muscle marked below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The muscle marked is the piriformis, which plays a key anatomical role in the posterolateral pelvic wall and is closely related to the sciatic nerve.

  • Origin: Anterior surface of the sacrum, sacrotuberous ligament, and capsule of the sacroiliac joint
  • Insertion: Greater trochanter of the femur (via the superior border)
  • Action: Lateral rotation of the thigh in extension, and abduction of the thigh when flexed
  • Relevance to sciatica: The sciatic nerve typically exits below the piriformis through the greater sciatic foramen. In some anatomical variants, the nerve or its branches pass through or above the muscle, making it prone to compression → piriformis syndrome, a cause of sciatica.
  • The piriformis is thus both a landmark and a potential site of entrapment neuropathy.

Explanation of other options:

Gamellus superior (Option A): Lies below the piriformis and assists in lateral rotation; not the main compressive site in sciatica.

Gluteus Maximus (Option B): Large superficial gluteal muscle; sciatic nerve lies deep to it, but not compressed by it directly.

Quadratus femoris (Option D): Lies inferior to obturator internus; not directly implicated in sciatic nerve entrapment.

Key Takeaway:

Piriformis muscle inflammation or hypertrophy can compress the sciatic nerve and cause classic sciatica symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of the superficial perineal pouch?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The bulbourethral glands are located in the deep perineal pouch, not the superficial one.

  • The superficial perineal pouch is a potential space between the perineal membrane (superior boundary) and the membranous layer of superficial perineal fascia (Colle'fascia, inferior boundary).
  • It contains:
    • Erectile tissues: crura (corpora cavernosa), bulb (corpus spongiosum in males, bulbs of the vestibule in females)
    • Skeletal muscles: bulbospongiosus, ischiocavernosus, and superficial transverse perineal
    • In females, it includes greater vestibular (Bartholin's) glands, situated posterolateral to the vaginal orifice.

In contrast, the bulbourethral glands (Cowper's glands in males) lie superior to the perineal membrane, within the deep perineal pouch.

Explanation of other options:

Root of penis (Option A): Formed by crura and bulb; part of superficial perineal pouch.

Bulbospongiosus muscle (Option B): Skeletal muscle overlying the bulb; located in the superficial pouch.

Great vestibular glands (Option C): Present in females; located in the superficial perineal pouch.

Key Takeaway:

Bulbourethral glands are found in the deep perineal pouch, whereas the superficial perineal pouch contains erectile tissues and associated muscles.

choices.text: The bulbourethral glands lie in the deep perineal pouch in males.
The root of the penis is located within the superficial perineal pouch.
The external urethral sphincter lies in the superficial perineal pouch.
The dorsal nerve of the penis passes through the deep perineal pouch.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the superficial and deep perineal pouches is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The external urethral sphincter (sphincter urethrae) lies in the deep perineal pouch, not the superficial one.

  • The superficial perineal pouch lies between Colles' fascia (below) and the perineal membrane (above).
    • Contents: Root of penis/clitoris (bulb and crura), bulbospongiosus, ischiocavernosus, superficial transverse perineal muscles.
  • The deep perineal pouch lies between the perineal membrane (below) and the superior fascia of the urogenital diaphragm (above).
    • Contents: Sphincter urethrae, deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbourethral glands (in males), membranous urethra, dorsal nerve and vessels of the penis/clitoris.

Key Takeaway:

Sphincter urethrae is a component of the deep perineal pouch, not the superficial perineal pouch.

questions.text: Suppose the venous drainage of the anal canal above the pectinate line is impaired in a patient with portal hypertension. In that case, there may be an increase in blood flow downward to the systemic venous system via anastomoses with the inferior rectal vein, which is a tributary of the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The inferior rectal vein is a systemic tributary of the internal pudendal vein, forming a key component of the portosystemic anastomosis at the rectum.

  • Above the pectinate line, venous blood drains into the superior rectal vein, a tributary of the inferior mesenteric vein (portal system).
  • Below the pectinate line, drainage occurs via the middle and inferior rectal veins, which connect to the internal iliac vein through the internal pudendal vein (systemic circulation).
  • In portal hypertension, venous blood can be diverted through these anastomoses into the systemic system, leading to internal haemorrhoids.

Explanation of other options:

External iliac (Option A): Drains the lower limb and does not receive venous drainage from the rectum.

Inferior gluteal (Option B): Drains the gluteal region and is unrelated to rectal venous drainage.

Inferior mesenteric (Option C): Part of the portal system and the origin of the superior rectal vein-not a systemic tributary.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rectal venous plexus is a site of portocaval anastomosis.
  • Inferior rectal vein drains into internal pudendal → internal iliac → IVC (systemic pathway).
  • In portal hypertension, this collateral pathway becomes prominent and may result in haemorrhoids.
